title.abbrev: ECDSA and SHA-256 Algorithms for SSHFP

front.title: Use of SHA-256 Algorithm with RSA, DSA and ECDSA in SSHFP Resource Records

abstract.t: This document defines how to store Secure Shell (SSH) ECDSA public keys and SHA-256 fingerprints in SSHFP Resource Records.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Domain Name System (DNS) is the global, hierarchical distributed database for Internet Naming. The Secure Shell (SSH) is a protocol for secure remote login and other secure network services over an insecure network. RFC 4253 defines Public Key Algorithms for the Secure Shell server public keys.

The DNS has been extended to store fingerprints in a DNS recource record named SSHFP , which provide out-of-band verification by looking up a fingerprint of the server public key in the DNS , and using DNSSEC , , to verify the lookup.

RFC 4255 describes how to store SSH public keys in SSHFP resource records and specifies a list of cryptographic algorithms to use for Algorithm Number and Fingerprint Type. This document extendes the SSHFP Algorithm Number list with the ECDSA algorithm which has been added to Secure Shell Public Key list in RFC 5656 and the SSHFP Fingerprint Type list with SHA-256 algorithm.
Familiarity with DNSSEC, SSH Protocol , , , SSHFP , and the SHA-2 family of algorithms is assumed in this document.

section.title: SSHFP Resource Records
section.t: The format of the SSHFP RR can be found in RFC 4255.

section.title: SSHFP Fingerprint Type Specification
section.t: The fingerprint type octet describes the message-digest algorithm used to calculate the fingerprint of the public key.

section.title: SHA-256 SSHFP Fingerprint Type Specification
section.t: SHA-256 fingerprints of the public keys are stored in SSHFP Resource Record with the fingerprint type 2.

section.title: SSHFP Algorithm Number Specification
section.t: The SSHFP Resource Record algorithm number octet describes the algorithm of the public key.

section.title: ECDSA SSHFP Algorithm Number Specification
section.t: ECDSA public keys are stored in SSHFP Resource Records with the algorithm number 3.
ECDSA public key fingerprints MUST use SHA-256 algorithm fingerprint.

section.title: Support for SHA-256 fingerprints
section.t: SSHFP-aware Secure Shell implementations SHOULD support the SHA-256 fingerprints for verification of the public key. Secure Shell implementations which support SHA-256 fingerprints MUST prefer the SHA-256 fingerprints if available over SHA-1 to prevent downgrade attacks.

section.title: Support for ECDSA
section.t: SSHFP-aware Secure Shell implementations which also implement ECDSA algorithm for the public key SHOULD support SSHFP fingerprints for ECDSA public keys.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Please see the security considerations in for SSHFP record and for ECDSA algorithm.

Users of SSHFP are encouraged to deploy SHA-256 as soon as software implementations allow for it. SHA-2 family of algorithms is widely believed to be more resilient to attack than SHA-1, and confidence in SHA-1's strength is being eroded by recently announced attacks. Regardless of whether or not the attacks on SHA-1 will affect SSHFP, it is believed (at the time of this writing) that SHA-256 is the better choice for use in SSHFP records.
SHA-256 is considered sufficiently strong for the immediate future, but predictions about future development in cryptography and cryptanalysis are beyond the scope of this document.
